title: There‚Äôs No Such Thing as ‚ÄúAccurate‚Äù Search Volume
description: ...and even if there was, you wouldn't need it.

And last time I announced our newest addition to Keywords Explorer, someone replied with this:I mean it is good for seasonal keywords but to be honest it would be great if the search volume in general would be more accurate‚Ä¶‚Äî Kim von D√§niken (@KimvonDaniken) March 6, 2024 Which was not the first time I saw us being criticized for the accuracy of our search volume metric.But here‚Äôs the kicker‚Ä¶There‚Äôs NO SUCH THING as an accurate search volume:The volumes in Google Keyword Planner aren‚Äôt accurate.The ‚ÄúImpressions‚Äù in GSC aren‚Äôt accurate either.And the metric itself is just an average of the past data.I already published a pretty detailed article about the search volume metric back in 2021. But I don‚Äôt think too many people have read it.‚ÄúEverything that needs to be said has already been said. But since no one was listening, everything must be said again.‚ÄùAndr√© Gide So let me address this topic from a whole new angle.ContentsSearch volumes in Google Keyword Planner aren‚Äôt accurateFirst of all, what do SEOs even mean when they ask for search volumes to be ‚Äúaccurate?‚ÄùWell, the less experienced folks just want the metrics in third-party tools to match what they see in Google Keyword Planner (GKP).But the more experienced ones already know all Google Keyword Planner‚Äôs Dirty Secrets:The numbers are rounded annual averages.Those averages are then assigned to ‚Äúvolume buckets.‚ÄùKeywords with similar meaning are often grouped together and their search volume summed up.In other words, the search volume numbers that you see in GKP are very different from the number of ‚Äúreal‚Äù searches each keyword gets. And once SEOs learn that, they no longer use GKP as their baseline of accuracy.They use GSC.Search volumes in Google Search Console aren‚Äôt accurate eitherOk. So the numbers in GKP are rounded and bucketed and clustered together and all that. But Google Search Console (GSC) shows you the actual impressions for a given keyword, right?Well, did you know that a simple rank-tracking tool can easily pollute your GSC impressions?What it looks like when the only impressions are coming from other SEOs‚Äô rank trackers. üòë pic.twitter.com/v1gYnvuQJ4‚Äî Joy Hawkins (@JoyanneHawkins) October 31, 2023 Think of how many different ‚Äúrobots‚Äù might be scraping the search results for a given keyword, and therefore giving you a fairly inaccurate impression of its real (human-driven) search volume.And besides, in order to see the actual monthly search volume your page has to be ranking at the top 10 for thirty days straight. And it should rank nationwide, just in case the search results might differ based on the location.On top of that, I‚Äôm sure GSC is no different from any other analytics tool in the sense that it might have certain discrepancies in ‚Äúcounting‚Äù those impressions. I mean, go compare the ‚ÄúClicks‚Äù you see reported by GSC with your server log files. I bet the numbers won‚Äôt match.Search volume metrics show the past, not the futureHow much time do you think would pass between you selecting a certain keyword to rank for and actually having your page rank at the top of Google for it?According to our old research, it could be anywhere from two months to a year for a newly published page to get to the top. Don‚Äôt you think the monthly search volume of a given keyword will change by then?That‚Äôs actually the exact reason why we‚Äôve added search volume forecasting to our Keywords Explorer tool. It uses past data to project what would likely happen to search volume in the next 12 months:Is it accurate? No.But does it help to streamline your keyword research and make better decisions? Absolutely.Imagine that search volume WAS accurateLet‚Äôs do a thought experiment and imagine that there was an SEO tool which would give you a highly accurate search volume for any keyword. What would you use it for? Would you be able to predict your real search traffic from that keyword?No!You can‚Äôt know for sure at which position your page will end up ranking. Today it‚Äôs #3, tomorrow it‚Äôs #5, the day after is #1. Rankings are volatile and you rarely retain a given position for a long enough period of time.And even if you did: you can‚Äôt get accurate data on the click-through rate (CTR) of each position in Google. Each SERP is unique, and Google keeps rolling out more and more SERP features that steal clicks away. So even if you knew exactly the search volume of a keyword and the exact position where your page would sit‚Ä¶ you still would not be able to calculate the accurate amount of search traffic that you‚Äôll get.And finally‚Ä¶Pages don‚Äôt rank for a single keyword! Seven years ago we published a study showing that a typical page that ranks at the top of Google for some keyword would actually rank for about a thousand more related keywords.So what‚Äôs the point of trying to gauge your clicks from a single keyword, when you‚Äôll end up ranking for a thousand of them all at the same time?And the takeaway from all this is‚Ä¶‚ÄúDirectionally accurate‚Äù is accurate enoughHere at Ahrefs we spend a tremendous amount of time, effort and resources to make sure our keyword database is in good shape, both in terms of its coverage of existing search queries, and the SEO metrics we give you for each of these keywords.None of our SEO metrics are ‚Äúaccurate‚Äù though. Not search volume, nor keyword difficulty, nor traffic potential, you name it.But none of them can be.They‚Äôre designed to be ‚Äúdirectionally accurate.‚Äù They give you an overall idea of the search demand of a given keyword and if it‚Äôs a lot higher (or lower) compared to some other keywords which you are considering.You can‚Äôt use those metrics to work out the ‚Äúreal‚Äù search volume or click-through rate of keywords.But hundreds of thousands of SEO professionals around the world are using these exact metrics to guide their SEO strategies and they get precisely the results that they expect to get.
